content.div:
Said The Whale

Little Mountain

(Hidden Pony)

With 2009's Islands Disappear, Said The Whale climbed a little mountain of fame -- earning radio play for "Camilo (The Magician)," shooting a road doc for CBC and winning Best New Group at last year's Junos. With Little Mountain, the Vancouver folk-rockers might not make it over the next peak -- the 15-song collection feels like its missing some of the oomph from their previous album and live shows. A few tunes, such as "Lover/Friend" and "Guilty Hypocrties," are lifeless snippets. Others are charming and snappy ditties, such as "Heavy Ceiling" and "Jesse, AR," yet they feel almost too clean and concise, given the tempestuousness of their subject matters. "Didn't take a couple months till Jesse finally met someone / A simple girl from Edmonton," Tyler Bancroft sings on the latter, a track about inner angst and trying to change your life. Even some of their road-tested tunes -- such as the sublime chant-along "We Are 1980" -- don't match the intensity and grit of Said The Whale's sweat-and euphoria-filled shows. Little Mountain is a strong collection of tunes, but their production lets them down.

Rating: 3.5 out of 5

--Sandra Sperounes, Postmedia News

--

Andrew Bird

Break It Yourself

(Mom + Pop)

"The moon plays the ocean like a violin," Andrew Bird observes on "Sifters." Bird, meanwhile, plays the violin like an ocean, with cresting waves and unfathomable depths. The saws, swoops and taps in "Desperation Breeds" outline his range, while leaving considerable space between the notes. Like most of Break It Yourself, it's both understated and dazzling -- the mark of an artist who knows his talents but doesn't need to prove his virtuosity. Bird's interest in polyrhythms has intensified, as has an interest in distended song structures and nocturnal wonder. If it takes time to get lost in the fantasy world of the eight-minute "Hole in the Ocean Floor," though, the Broken Social Scene-style organized cacophony of "Eyeoneye" and "Lazy Projector's" sentimental heart are strikingly immediate.

Rating: 4 out of 5

--Jordan Zivitz, Postmedia News

--

Bruce Springsteen

Wrecking Ball

(Columbia)

The last time Bruce Springsteen checked in with a new studio album, the subpar Working on a Dream, Barack Obama's inauguration speech was ringing in our ears.

"Homes have been lost, jobs shed, businesses shuttered," the commander-in-chief had said before offering a message of hope. Three years later, The Boss -- in an explicitly political album -- surveys the landscape and finds things as bad as ever. Maybe worse.

And yet, as he makes clear in the rousing opener "We Take Care of Our Own," the dream never dies as long as people help each other out. The song starts by quoting the Beach Boys' "Wild Honey" before settling into an E Street Band-style rocker, slightly dialed down by a post-Seeger Sessions roots approach. "There ain't no help, the cavalry stayed home / There ain't no one hearing the bugle blowin," Springsteen sings.

He keeps returning to the twin themes of abandonment and courage, notably in the stirring title track, with its celebration of resilience in the face of disaster. There's also optimism in the new-day-coming resolution of "Rocky Ground," which features an unnecessary rap section by gospel singer Michelle Moore.

But the persistence of hope is only the good news, because -- make no mistake -- Springsteen is angry. While there are several singalong, fist-pumping mission statements-in-waiting here, there are also villains in almost every song. And in true Woody Guthrie style, they're likely to be found in a bank sticking it to the working man. On the pensive piano ballad "Jack of All Trades," the down-and-out but undefeated protagonist even gives voice to a violent impulse. Like Ry Cooder's "Pull Up Some Dust and Sit Down," this disc could be the perfect soundtrack to Occupy Wall Street.

In the wonderful "Shackled and Drawn," there's no room for ambiguity. "Gambling man rolls the dice / Workingman pays the bill / It's still fat and easy up on banker's hill," Springsteen sings. And on the similarly Celtic-flavoured "Death to My Hometown," no doubt is left as to who brought it there.

Among the disc's more daring moves is its mildly experimental sound: with its samples, loops and sometimes filtered guitar work, it's hardly heartland rock by the numbers. For example, "Land of Hope and Dreams," an upbeat anthem to end them all, intriguingly recasts another song, centring its theme of brotherhood on the Impressions classic "People Get Ready."

The song also features a sax solo by Springsteen's E Street foil Clarence Clemons, who died last year. This is where the Big Man really says goodbye to the fans. Or does he? "Clarence doesn't leave the E Street Band when he dies," Springsteen writes in the liner notes. "He leaves when we die."

And there's life ahead, to be sure. "Though our bodies lie alone here in the dark / Our souls and spirits rise / To carry the fire and light the spark / To fight shoulder to shoulder and heart to heart," Springsteen sings in the triumphant closer "We Are Alive," which musically exhumes Johnny Cash's "Ring of Fire" for one last celebratory lap.

As John Lydon once reminded us, anger is an energy.

Rating: 4 out of 5

--Bernard Perusse, Postmedia News

--

Chairlift

Something

(Columbia)

Remember when male-female duos, such as The White Stripes and The Kills, were something of a novelty? These days, pairing up seems to be the coolest configuration, especially in the electro-pop world -- what with such buzzworthy acts as Crystal Castles, Sleigh Bells, Karmin, La Roux, Handsome Furs and The Ting Tings. Then, there's Chairlift, a trio-turned-duo after vocalist Caroline Polachek's ex-boyfriend skied off on his own -- and Something only benefits from his absence. The album, featuring Polachek and multi-instrumentalist Patrick Wimberley, is taut, snappy and sinister -- almost everything their woozy 2008 debut, Does You Inspire You, wasn't. "Poi-son seems old-fashioned / And hired help's no fun / But I do know how to drive a car / Faster than a man can run," she warns on "Sidewalk Safari," one of 11 tracks which hover toward the icier and quirkier side of '80s pop. (Think Jane Siberry, Bruce Cockburn, The Thompson Twins and Blancmange.) While Polachek's lyrics seem bolder than ever, her pipes are even more so -- brimming with confidence as she dips between octaves, accents and textures. Nowhere is this more evident than on "Ama-naemonesia," where she flits from dreamy pixie to nonchalant Brit to manly witch. This Something is quite magical.

Rating: 4 out of 5

Sandra Sperounes, Postmedia News

--

Estelle

All of Me

(Home School/Atlantic/Warner)

With her Grammy-winning 2008 hit "American Boy" (featuring Kanye West) and an album on John Legend's Home School label, British starlet Estelle seemed to be on her way. But a long four years later, she still hasn't quite found her groove. An edgy pair of opening tracks, "The Life" and "International (Serious)," show off her ease at mixing hip-hop, dance-hall reggae and R&B, but the latter fails with a Chris Brown cameo. She gets into classic soul with the retro-style "Cold Crush" and "Break My Heart" (featuring Rick Ross, released last summer to modest success), and evokes Sade on the Akon-penned "Thank You." Wyclef, Ne-Yo and Janelle Monae help out in the home stretch, and Estelle keeps up. But she never pulls it all together into something distinctly her own.

Rating: 3 out of 5

--T'Cha Dunlevy, Postmedia News

--

The Magnetic Fields

Love at the Bottom of the Sea

(Merge)

Stephin Merritt likes to compartmentalize his art, which often makes a new Magnetic Fields album sound reinvigorating or, in this case, disorienting. Coming after a soi-disant "no-synth trilogy," Love at the Bottom of the Sea is a partial return to the Fields' 1990s plasticized arrangements. Partial because, as if to emphasize the new/old direction, Merritt's effortless bedroom pop is slathered with blorpy, glorpy synth effects, in contrast to the playful elegance of his early albums. Perhaps it's a masking device for songs that stay near the shallow end of his deep talent pool -- the jokes in "I'd Go Anywhere with Hugh" and "Infatuation (with Your Gyration)" don't stretch far beyond the titles. But then there's "Andrew in Drag" and the full-on cabaret number "Born for Love," whose emotional hooks cut through layers of ephemeral decoration and belie Merritt's reputation as an incurable hangdog.

Rating: 3 out of 5

--Jordan Zivitz, Postmedia News

entry.title: Photos: Estelle and More Rip the Runway

link.Abstract: BET's Rip the Runway doesn't air until March 21, but we've already got photos from the network's annual celebration of music, fashion and sexxxy supermodels. Check out pics of performances by Estelle, Lil Kim, Wale, Robin Thicke, B.o.B. and more.

link.title: Photos: Kanye West, Jay-Z and Nicki Minaj at the Victoria's Secret Fashion Show

link.Abstract: Nicki Minaj released new song "Stupid Hoe" today. The lyrics would seem to confirm that she'll appear at the Super Bowl with Madonna (and also that she thinks someone is a "stupid hoe").

link.Abstract: Listen to "Give Me All Your Love," a sugary new song thought to be a leak of Madonna's new single.
